unnormalised: Okay, so GST, or Goods and Services Tax, can seem super complicated, right? It's this single indirect tax that replaced a bunch of other taxes like excise duty, VAT, and service tax back on 1st July 2017. The idea was to simplify things and create a unified market across India. But let's be honest, it still leaves many of us scratching our heads.
normalised: Okay, so G-S-T, or Goods and Services Tax, can seem super complicated, right? It's this single indirect tax that replaced a bunch of other taxes like excise duty, V-A-T, and service tax back on first July two thousand seventeen. The idea was to simplify things and create a unified market across India. But let's be honest, it still leaves many of us scratching our heads.

unnormalised: Basically, it's a multi-stage, destination-based tax. Think of it like this: every time something gets added to the value of a product or service, tax is applied. And the final tax goes to the state where the product is consumed, not where it's made. Makes sense? Sort of?

unnormalised: There are different rates depending on what you’re buying. Some essentials are exempt, some are at 5%, and others go up to 12%, 18%, or even 28%. Gold, for instance, has a GST rate of 3%. You can find the exact rates for specific goods and services on the CBIC (Central Board of Indirect Taxes and Customs) website. Make sure you check the updated list as of today, 20/07/2024.

unnormalised: Now, businesses with a turnover of over Rs. 20 lakh (Rs. 10 lakh for some special category states) have to register for GST. Once registered, they get a GSTIN – a Goods and Services Tax Identification Number – which they use for all their transactions. They also need to file GST returns monthly or quarterly, depending on their chosen scheme.
normalised: Now, businesses with a turnover of over rupee twenty lakh (rupee ten lakh for some special category states) have to register for G-S-T. Once registered, they get a G-S-T-I-N – a Goods and Services Tax Identification Number – which they use for all their transactions. They also need to file G-S-T returns monthly or quarterly, depending on their chosen scheme.

unnormalised: One of the big benefits of GST is the concept of input tax credit (ITC). If a business pays GST on its purchases, it can claim that as a credit when it pays GST on its sales. This helps avoid the cascading effect of taxes, where tax is levied on tax. However, claiming ITC can be tricky, so it's always a good idea to consult a CA (Chartered Accountant) to make sure you're doing it right. For instance, Sec 16 of CGST Act covers eligibility for ITC.
normalised: One of the big benefits of G-S-T is the concept of input tax credit (I-T-C). If a business pays G-S-T on its purchases, it can claim that as a credit when it pays G-S-T on its sales. This helps avoid the cascading effect of taxes, where tax is levied on tax. However, claiming I-T-C can be tricky, so it's always a good idea to consult a C-A (Chartered Accountant) to make sure you're doing it right. For instance, S-e-c sixteen of C-G-S-T Act covers eligibility for I-T-C.
